abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the First Agriculture
            Project is rated as unsatisfactory, sustainability as
            likely, institutional development impact as modest, Bank
            performance as unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance as
            satisfactory. Moldova was a relatively new borrower.
            Simultaneous preparation of multiple projects for a new
            client country as overly ambitious, and, in the end, led to
            costly project preparation with limited development impact.
            Project design should be kept simple. There should have been
            clear distinctions between public and private investments.
            Initiating investment projects in an unstable environment is
            risky but particularly so when support is given to
            state-owned entities where major restructuring is looming.
            High quality, state of the art equipment given to
            non-reformed institutions in the public sector did not
            necessarily improve the overall effectiveness of the
            research institutes. Research should be funded by the
            government, rather than requiring research institutes to
            divert their efforts to commercial activities. When a loan
            from an international financial institution is being
            utilized, repayment matters should be addressed up front,
            with cost recovery and repayment terms and conditions
            clearly defined in the project document and properly
            monitored during implementation. A public investment should
            be clearly defined up-front, and specify appropriate cost
            recovery rates. Support for research should have clear
            linkages to the farming community.

            AGRO-ENTERPRISES RESTRUCT.,TF033580-ECA REGION (MOLDOVA, ESTONIA) - AGRICULTURE,TF034934-MOLDOVA - FIRST AGRICULTURE PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the First Agriculture
            Project are to: 1) upgrade and improve the effectiveness of
            key agricultural research programs on priority export crops
            and products; 2) strengthen institutions in priority areas:
            the agricultural knowledge system; product quality
            regulatory functions; and management in the post-privatized
            agro-processing sector; 3) develop capabilities to prepare
            sector investments and develop sector policy; and 4) develop
            project management and implementation capacity for the
            agriculture investment program. The project will comprise
            the following components: 1) agro-technology development and
            transfer consisting of viticulture and horticulture
            improvement, animal breeding and integrated pest management;
            2) institutional strengthening including studies and
            training; 3) project preparation and policy development; and
            4) project management.
